qas.question: What is the average concentration of copper in ores?
What does heating copper ore materials with silica remove?
What happens to the silicate slag  during the flash smelting process?
What do the sulfides convert to after the copper matte is roasted?
What is the average concentration of copper in holes?
What does freezing copper ore materials with silica remove?
What happens to the silicate slag during the flash freezing process?
What do the sulfides convert to after the copper matte is frozen?

context: The concentration of copper in ores averages only <a0_0><b5_0>0.6%<b5_0/><a0_0/>, and most commercial ores are <a1_0>sulfides<a1_0/>, especially chalcopyrite (CuFeS2) and to a lesser extent chalcocite (Cu2S). These minerals are concentrated from crushed ores to the level of 10–15% copper by froth flotation or bioleaching. Heating this material with silica in flash smelting removes much of the <a2_0><b7_0>iron<b7_0/><a2_0/> as slag. The process exploits the greater ease of converting iron sulfides into its oxides, which in turn react with the silica to form the silicate slag, which <a3_0><b8_0>floats on top<b8_0/><a3_0/> of the heated mass. The resulting copper matte consisting of Cu2S is then roasted to convert all <b6_0>sulfides<b6_0/> into <a4_0><b9_0>oxides<b9_0/><a4_0/>:
